title: Improving Categorisation in Social Media using Hyperlinks to Structured Data Sources

author: Sheila Kinsella, DERI Galway, National University of Ireland, Galway

segmentation: I'm Sheila Kinsella.

I'm a PhD student at Derry, Galway and this is joint works with my colleagues, Mingzhu Wang, John Breslin and Connor Hayes, and we've been looking at how to improve the topic categorization of social media posts using hyperlinks to structured data sources.
So first just to introduce topic categorization.
Basically, given a set of classes or topics, then we want to determine what class are given document belongs to.
So in the case of social media that the document is opposed and this is usually done based on the content of a document or a post.
And the applications for doing this in social media are that.
First of all, we can categorize existing posts for enhanced browsing.
So for example, we could categorize Twitter posts to allow us to praise them by topic.
The other example of an application is if we want to suggest categories for new posts on creation.
So this applies to a kind of site like a message board divided into categories by topic, where the user has to decide actually where they're supposed to create the post.
Because often a message boards people actually don't know which section of the site they should post in.
So if you could categorize the topic of the post for them then this would help them with that.
So the challenges for classifying social media posts are first of all, they're very short and informal, so there's not a lot of content there to base your classification on.

The second point is that they very often rely on hyperlinks for context, so here is an example of a typical post an from our message board data set, and it says anyone read this worth the read and there is a link to an Amazon product.
Which we assume is a book, but we don't really know what the post is about.
Um, on the other hand, if you follow this hyperlink and look at the metadata of the object, then you can see from the title that it's about ultimate fighting and the martial arts revolution.
You can see that the categories are sports and boxing and martial arts, and you can also see the author name, so this is all really useful information to help us understand that.
Look up the post.
So our motivation for trying to improve classification using hyperlinks is that as we just saw.
The post often contain hyperlinks which point to objects which are the topic of the post.

So if somebody is writing a post about a movie, then they're really often linked to that movie on IMDb, or if someone is talking about some other concepts, then they might provide a link to the Wikipedia article in order to let people look that up for reference.
And these hyperlinks often contain knew and useful information.

So in a forum datasets that I introduced later, we looked at all of the posts which had hyperlinks to books on Amazon, and we found that 65% of the posts didn't mention the complete title or author of the book that they linked to, and at least 11% didn't contain any single word from the title or the author.
So basically people enough people often post these links, but they don't really describe very well the resource that they're linking to.

And even though these hyperlinks only occur in a subset of posts and we found from looking at the data that actually the posts which of hyperlinks are quite likely to be a useful source of information, because often posts are just trash like somebody says lol or plus one or I had such a bad day.
But in the posts where people post hyperlinks then they very often actually have some kind of informative information there.
So I think that being able to classify these posts pressure is of special importance.
The second part of the motivation.
So how do we concentrate unstructured data sources?
Well, very often people don't just link to documents which have text, but they link to objects which have metadata describing different aspects of the object.
And if this is expressed in a structured way, then that enables us to extract the most relevant data.
So instead of looking at a whole HTML page which might have advertisements and comments and someone related information, then we can actually just select the metadata.
Which is the most relevant part of the page about the object?
And we can also experimentally identify which of these are most useful, because you have lots of different types of metadata, and it's very likely that some of those will be more useful than others.

And recently, the amount of this data that's available is growing, so a few years ago probably it wouldn't make sense to do this, but now, actually, there's enough data that making use of this does make sense.
So in our message board data set of the posts with hyperlinks, then 23% of those linked to at least one object which did have structured data available either from an API or as linked data.
So to give an overview of our approach.
So first of all we identify this, sort the good sources of structured data in the data set, and we did this based on domains, so every for her we see a link to wikipedia.org.
We know that there is a structured representation available for that resource on DB pedia.
We then retrieve this structured data either from linked data where it's available or else via API's.
And for our experiments we also retrieved the HTML representation just for comparison.
We perform text classification for our experiments.
We used a naive Bayes classifier and this requires a set of already categorized posts for training.
So you need to be able to learn the topics from some set of posts which already have a topic assigned.
We use the post content and the external metadata as sources of textual features for the classifier.

And we compare the accuracy achieved by different metadata types and this is related to studies and information retrieval which classify web documents based on fielded text from hyperlink pages, but they typically consider structural data.
So for example, they take the headings of a web page, whereas we can consider semantic fields.
So we can look at the genre over resource or the author of resource or the tags of a resource.
So we looked at two different datasets because we wanted to see how your findings compared across different types of social media.
So the first column here, the Forum column and this data set is from a message board.
The ground truth topics that we took here were the different forums within the message board, so it's a message board which is divided into different sections by topic.
For example, there is a soccer for Amanda Books Forum and so on.
And we chose ten of those topics for our experiments, with a total of six point 6000 posts.
The second data set that we looked at was from Twitter, which is a microblogging site, and in this case we chose hashtags as the topics.

So we took some popular hashtags in the data set, including games and books, and we assume that posts which are assigned to these hashtags belong to that category, because often people use hashtags as a way of indicating what the topic of their tweeters.
So we chose 6 topics there and a total of two point 4000 posts belonging to those and all of these posts have a hyperlink to some source of structured data.
Are the sources of structured data that we looked at.
Shown here, so for every post which links to a Wikipedia article, then we retrieve the representation from DB pedia.
For every post which links to music artist on Myspace, then we retrieved the metadata from the beach and and for all of the IMDb movies.
Then we retrieved metadata from the linked movie database.
We also considers three web APIs, so we got product metadata from Amazon photo metadata from Flickr and video metadata from YouTube.
So this gives you an idea of the different objects that were linked to in each of the categories.
So across the bottom here you see the different forums that we considered in our message board data set and then you can see what different kind of objects and made up the posts in each category.
So for example in the first column there the Photography Forum, then the vast majority of the links were to Flickr photos.
Not surprisingly, in the third column the Musicians Forum then.
Most of these links were to music artists an in the fourth column.
The movies category, then most of the hyperlinks were to movies in IMDb.
And then in the other categories there was more of a mixture of links, so very often 2 YouTube videos and two Wikipedia articles.
So this is the experiment slash we carried out.
We used our multinomial naive Bayes classifier which is implemented in the Wacker toolkit.
We applied TF IDF normalization and document length normalization and we lower cased all of the terms removed stop words and removed non alphabetic characters.

We performed a 10 fold cross validation so we divided the data set into 10 folds and we did ten runs of classification experiments where on each run we use one fold as the test set and the other nine folds as the training set.
And then we take the average of these as our final results.
We compared the classification accuracy for different post representations.
So based on features from post content from the hyperlinked HTML pages and from the hyperlinked object metadata.
And we experimented to find the optimal ways of combining these feature vectors.
So if we want to combine the features from post content and from post metadata, then we experimented what gave the best results.
So for example, what were the best weightings to use?
And this is just a summary of the different representations we considered.
So first of all, we looked at the post content with URLs removed and then the content with URLs present to see how much help tokens from URLs were for figuring out the topic of the post.

We also considered just the HTML pages which were linked to and then we considered the metadata from hyperlinked objects because we wanted to compare different types of metadata, we chose some particular types that are very popular.
So specifically Title, description or abstract.
In the case of DB pedia resource is.
Tags, categories or genre and finally author director, but in theory you could could use any arbitrary metadata which exists for a resource.
Then finally we looked at the combinations of content plus HTML pages and content plus metadata.

So here are the results for the single sources of textual information, and if we look first of all at the results for forum, you can see that the F score for classification based just on the post content is .745.
And then if you include URL information this increases 2.811.
And this is because, for example, if a post links to a Myspace artist, then that's already a very good clue that it belongs to the Musicians Forum.
So already just by considering URL tokens, then you get some extra information.

If you look at the results for HTML, that's performs relatively poorly, and then if you look at the results for external metadata, then this actually gives the highest result and these results are statistically significant at a 90% confidence level.
So for the forum data set, we found that to classify the topic of the post we got better results just from the metadata.
So without even considering the post content, then classification based on the actual content of the post.

For the Twitter data slash we got slightly different results, so again we see that I'm classification based on content with URLs is better than classification based on content without and again the HTML performs quite poorly.
But here the metadata also performed relatively poorly under theory.

For that is that when people post hyperlinks on Twitter then they usually they're trying to share this and encourage their friends to read it so they actually do give a pretty good description of the resource.

So you do actually get good features of the topic there, whereas in the message board people usually just sort of put in the link to give reference to author talking about or to give extra information, and they typically don't describe it as well.
So in the message board data set we found that the external metadata was a particularly useful source of information about the topic.
So what I'm showing here is just when we add in the results for the two combined representations.
Um, we see that if you classify based on content and HTML, it does perform significantly better than classification based on post content alone.
So bringing in information from HTML pages does help, but if you bring in the information from metadata, so content plus metadata, then the results are significantly better.
So we see here that for both datasets we get much better classification accuracy if we use the information from external metadata.
It's also interesting to look at the results for topic and Forum, so here we were comparing for each of the 10 different categories high.
The results were and the column here that I've highlighted in red shows that for every single category content plus metadata was the best performing representation.
But if we look at the change, so how much the accuracy improved?
Then we can see some interesting things.
So I've highlighted in blue here.
The ones that changed by quite a small amount and I've highlighted in green the ones that changed by a larger amount.
And if we look at what these are.

So first of all the musicians forum changes only slightly and this is because you already get good information by the fact that a link to my space indicates that it's in the musicians forum, and similarly for the Photography Forum.
We also don't get much extra information from metadata because we already know that if a post links to Flickr, then it probably belongs in the Photography forum.
And then the next item in blue is movies, which again is because links to IMDb are really strongly associated with the movies forum.
Then the other two forums where we only got slight improvements by including metadata where the politics forum and the Atheism forum.
And the reason for this is that these two forms actually contained a lot of links to Wikipedia articles, and Wikipedia articles have the title of the article in the URL.
So here we actually do already have metadata within the posts, because we already have the title of the article that's being linked to.

Then for the other five, cash agrees we get much larger improvements when we consider metadata, because in these cases we don't have these kind of clues from URLs of the topic of the resource, so we can see from here is that for certain topics where you don't catch these clues about the topic from the URL itself, then in these cases it's especially useful to Poland metadata from external sources.
So in a practical situation, if you're doing classification on the fly and you see that a post links to my space, then there's probably no point going to the father of pulling in that matter data.
You can already guess it's in the musicians forum, whereas if you don't get any information like that from the URL, then it could be useful to follow the URL and get the external metadata.
So now I'll show you the results where we compared the different types of metadata.

So we began by first identifying all of the posts in the forum data set which had links to Wikipedia articles and this came to a total of 1.6 thousand posts, and we classified these posts based only on specific types of Wikipedia metadata.
So in the column here, where you see content with no URLs, this shows the result of classification just using content.
And we achieved a net score of .76 here.
And the reason we look at content without URLs is because, as I said, Wikipedia articles have the title of the article in the URL.
So because we want to see what the effects are of bringing in the title, then we need to remove URLs from the posts to compare this.
So I've ordered these in terms of which metadata performed best and we see here the categories of an article given F score of .811.
So if you have a post which links to a Wikipedia article, then you're better off to classified the topic of the post based on the categories of the article instead of looking at the post content.
We also see that the description of the article which corresponds to the first paragraph performs quite well, but the title of the article doesn't actually perform so well.
And then the final column where we combined content and metadata for all of the different types of metadata.
Then this gives better results.
We did something similar for YouTube videos, so we identified all of the posts and forum which link to YouTube videos.
This came to 2000 posts and again we classified these posts based only on the YouTube metadata.
So again I've shown the results for classification based only on the content and then classification based on the various types of metadata that you find in YouTube.
So we see here the tags gave the best performance.
With an F score of .838 compared to .7 or 9 for the post content.
So for posts which link to YouTube videos then those tags are a better indicator of the post topic than the post itself is.
We see here the title performs quite well.
Description Also performs quite well and the category performs very poorly.
And again, by actually combining the content plus the metadata, then we get better results again.
So we can see from these two slides that I'm the type of metadata matters a lot, and by looking at certain types of metadata, you get much better results.
So on this slide I've just shown the two tables from the previous slides together.
So here we can compare the effects of metadata types from different sites, and they're actually quite different.

So in the top table for Wikipedia you can see the category performs really well, whereas on YouTube the category performs really poorly, and that's because of course Wikipedia has this really rich category structure, and an article can belong to multiple categories, so you get a lot of topic information by looking at those.
Whereas on YouTube the videos only belong to one category and there's only about 10 different categories, so you don't get much information from those.
And if we look at title, for example, the title of Wikipedia articles doesn't really give a good description of the topic of the posts that link to those articles.
But for YouTube videos, the title performs quite well.
So if you're looking at metadata for different types of objects from different websites, then different types of metadata perform better depending on which website you're considering.
So just to give a summary of the results, we find that for our two datasets, then a combination of post content and metadata gave the best classification results.
We also notice that this improvement varies by and this depends on the characteristics of the URLs that usually occur within that category.
And finally, the most useful metadata types can be found experimentally, but for different objects.
Then the usefulness of different metadata types varies.
So just to give you an idea of some of our future directions.
Well, we've shown that standard information retrieval techniques can be improved by making use of semantic data sources.
And next we want to make more use of the semantic links becausw for the linked data sources.
You don't just have textual metadata, but you have this rich interconnected graph of entities.
So basically we want to move from using structural textual information to using the semantic links between related entities.
And just as we experimentally identified the most useful metadata types, then we could also use machine learning techniques to identify the most beneficial property paths between entities.
The next point is that with the large amounts of or DFA now available, you could actually greatly increase the coverage of this approach.
So when we were collecting data for these experiments, then all of that Facebook Open Graph protocol data wasn't available yet.
But if we were to rerun this now, then we could really include so many more hyperlinks in our analysis.
And finally, this isn't limited to social media, but basically any structure, any unstructured data which has links to sources of structured data.
Then we could use this approach to try and improve their classification.
So here I'm just showing an example of how I would imagine using semantic links for the topic classification.
So on the left hand side here in pink, I've shown some data from a social media site, so we have a post a which links to an article about Fawlty Towers and DB Pedia.
And we know that that belongs to the television category.
And below that we have a post beef which links to an article called Mr Bean and we don't know what the topic of that is.
But if we look at the graph on DB pedia, then we can actually find out that these two resources are really related.
So probably the posts are really related.
Becausw Fawlty Towers has a network of BBC Two.
Mr Bean has a network of ITV and these both belong to the category of television in the United Kingdom.
Um, also Fawlty Towers has a format of comedy.
Mr Bean has a format of physical comedy, and these both belong to the same category of comedy.
So, because these resources are so closely linked on the semantic graph, then we can probably figure out that post.
Be also should belong to the topic of television.
So to conclude, we found that topic classification in social media can be improved by making use of structured metadata from hyperlinked objects.

This shows how even unstructured web content can benefit by there being more structured data available on the web and linked data sources have the potential to give even more improvements by considering semantic links as well as textual metadata.
So thanks, and I'm happy to take any questions.
So do you go?
Thanks for the very interesting talk.
I have one question with regards to the structured sides that you take into consideration.
I'm wondering how would you deal with this being at the moment a hard coded list in a certain way?

And yeah, taking into account the long tail of very small structured sites that might not have the same important of IMDb, but be a very good movie website for indie movies, but you just don't know it yet because it's not in your hard coded list.
Yeah, so we basically just identified the most common.
Sources in the data set and worked with those.

But of course, if we were running this again then I think the most if we had time to look up every single hyperlink then we could basically follow everything and see if there's already a favor and pulled out, and so the main reason that we focused on these sources was just because we could easily identify already where there was structured data available and at the time we were collecting this a year or more ago then there wasn't so much or DFA there available.
But I'm yeah for this to to really make sense then.
You get a lot of benefit from considering all of these other sources, and one thing that's vital there, of course, is that they should be using or DFA becausw for three of our sources.
YouTube, Flickr, an Amazon.
We needed to write custom wrappers for their APIs, so making use of the long tail of APIs is difficult, but making use of the long tail of RDF is actually easy if it's there.
Further questions.
I'm so one thing that similar to that question.

So you said that around 20% actually had the metadata available off the page is being linked to, but this means basically the 20% of the links go to Wikipedia, IMDb and disorders in this small set of pages we have.
Is this correct or that's what it means?
Yeah, and that statement yeah made more sense when we were collecting the data.
Well, I mean there were also other sites with APIs, but I'm.
We basically just reported to the ones that we knew his structured data available, so yes, that actually only means that they link to Wikipedia or YouTube, or IMDb or so on.
I found you results very interesting, and I wonder whether you can give a little bit of clarification there and maybe just my confusion so.
Some of your results show that certain topics so metadata is useful for certain topics and not useful for other, not quite useful for other topics.
And then the other set of results shows that certain aspects of metadata are more useful.
So I wonder whether you consider the topics when you are reporting about the aspects of metadata.
So if I have metadata which is not useful, then what's the point of looking at what categories of that metadata is beneficial?
Right, So what we found there wasn't exactly that.
The metadata wasn't beneficial, but more that we already had clues from the URLs, so it just didn't add quite as much as an improvement as in other cases.
It's it's true that actually, for for a post for you already have an idea of the topic from the URL from the tokens from that, then looking at the metadata types isn't useful, but um.
In general, for the categories where we don't have clues about the topic from the URL's, then in those cases knowing which types of metadata perform best is useful.
Does that answer your question or?
OK, let's thank the speaker again.
